name: Intelligent Email Organization with AI-Powered Content Classification for Gmail

user.name: Niranjan G
user.bio: Cybersecurity leader turning complex workflows into seamless, AI-driven automations.

description:
This workflow leverages AI to intelligently analyze incoming Gmail messages and automatically apply relevant labels based on the email content.

The default configuration includes the following labels:

* **Newsletter**: Subscription updates or promotional content.
* **Inquiry**: Emails requesting information or responses.
* **Invoice**: Billing and payment-related emails.
* **Proposal**: Business offers or collaboration opportunities.
* **Action Required**: Emails demanding immediate tasks or actions.
* **Follow-up Reminder**: Emails prompting follow-up actions.
* **Task**: Emails containing actionable tasks.
* **Personal**: Non-work-related emails.
* **Urgent**: Time-sensitive or critical communications.
* **Bank**: Banking alerts and financial statements.
* **Job Update**: Recruitment or job-related communications.
* **Spam/Junk**: Unwanted or irrelevant bulk emails.
* **Social/Networking**: Notifications from social platforms.
* **Receipt**: Purchase confirmations and receipts.
* **Event Invite**: Invitations or calendar-related messages.
* **Subscription Renewal**: Reminders for subscription expirations.
* **System Notification**: Technical alerts from services or systems.

You can customize labels and definitions based on your specific use case.

### How it works:

* The workflow periodically retrieves new Gmail messages.
* Only emails without existing labels, regardless of read status, are sent to the AI for analysis.
* Email content (subject and body) is analyzed by an AI model to determine the appropriate label.
* Labels identified by the AI are applied to each email accordingly.

**Note:** This workflow performs 100% better than the default Gmail trigger method, which is why the workflow was switched from Gmail trigger to a scheduled workflow. By selectively processing only unlabeled emails, it ensures comprehensive labeling while significantly reducing AI processing costs.

### Setup Steps:

1. Configure credentials for Gmail and your chosen AI service (e.g., OpenAI).
2. Ensure labels exist in your Gmail account matching the workflow definitions.
3. Adjust the AI prompt to match your labeling needs.
4. Optionally customize the polling interval (default: every 2 minutes).

This workflow streamlines your email management, keeping your inbox organized effortlessly while optimizing resource usage.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

options.systemMessage:
You are my Personal Email Labeler.  
When I feed you the subject and body of a new email, you must assign exactly one label‚Äîno extra text.

Available labels:
- Newsletter  
- Inquiry  
- Invoice  
- Proposal  
- Action Required  
- Follow-up Reminder  
- Task  
- Personal  
- Urgent  
- Bank  
- Job Update  
- Spam / Junk  
- Social / Networking  
- Receipt  
- Event Invite  
- Subscription Renewal  
- System Notification  

Label definitions:
1. Newsletter  
   ‚Ä¢ Subscription updates, promotions, digests.  
   ‚Ä¢ No reply needed‚Äîjust file away.  
2. Inquiry  
   ‚Ä¢ Sender asks a question or requests information.  
   ‚Ä¢ Prioritize and suggest replying.  
3. Invoice  
   ‚Ä¢ Billing, receipts, payment requests.  
   ‚Ä¢ Flag if payment is due.  
4. Proposal  
   ‚Ä¢ Business offers, contracts, collaboration pitches.  
   ‚Ä¢ Flag for review; consider acknowledging receipt.  
5. Action Required  
   ‚Ä¢ Requests that demand you do something (book, confirm, complete).  
   ‚Ä¢ Mark and suggest a reminder.  
6. Follow-up Reminder  
   ‚Ä¢ Emails reminding you of something pending or that you already acted on.  
   ‚Ä¢ Suggest checking status or pinging again.  
7. Task  
   ‚Ä¢ Contains to-do items or project steps.  
   ‚Ä¢ Extract tasks, prioritize by deadline.  
8. Personal  
   ‚Ä¢ From friends or family; non-work.  
   ‚Ä¢ Keep accessible but low urgency unless marked urgent.  
9. Urgent  
   ‚Ä¢ Critical deadlines, emergencies, time-sensitive.  
   ‚Ä¢ Bump to top of your inbox; reply ASAP.  
10. Bank  
    ‚Ä¢ Statements, alerts, transaction notices, fraud warnings from your bank.  
    ‚Ä¢ Flag if action is needed (e.g., verify, transfer, dispute).  
11. Job Update  
    ‚Ä¢ Direct messages from recruiters/HR or alerts from job portals (LinkedIn, Naukri, etc.).  
    ‚Ä¢ Flag as relevant opportunity; suggest acknowledging or bookmarking.  
12. Spam / Junk  
    ‚Ä¢ Unwanted bulk mail, phishing attempts, obvious ads.  
    ‚Ä¢ Auto-archive or delete.  
13. Social / Networking  
    ‚Ä¢ Notifications from social sites (GitHub, Twitter, forums) not job-related.  
    ‚Ä¢ File separately from Job Update.  
14. Receipt  
    ‚Ä¢ E-commerce order confirmations, tickets, one-off purchase receipts.  
    ‚Ä¢ Archive after processing.  
15. Event Invite  
    ‚Ä¢ Calendar invitations or RSVPs (Google Meet, Zoom, Outlook).  
    ‚Ä¢ Accept/decline or add to calendar.  
16. Subscription Renewal  
    ‚Ä¢ Reminders for software licenses, memberships, domain renewals.  
    ‚Ä¢ Flag for manual renewal.  
17. System Notification  
    ‚Ä¢ Alerts from monitoring tools, CI/CD, cloud services, security scanners.  
    ‚Ä¢ Triage or forward to team channel.

Rules:
- Read subject + body.  
- Choose the single best label.  
- Output **only** that label.
